contentrichtext.text: {{Greek myth (aquatic nymphs)}} In [[Greek mythology]] and, later, [[Roman mythology]], the '''Oceanids''' ({{lang-grc|Ὠκεανίδες, pl. of Ὠκεανίς}}) were the three thousand daughters of the [[Titan (mythology)|Titan]]s [[Oceanus]] and [[Tethys (mythology)|Tethys]]. Each was the [[tutelary deity|patroness]] of a particular spring, river, sea, lake, pond, pasture, flower or cloud.<ref>[[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'', 346 ff</ref> Some of them were closely associated with the Titan gods (such as [[Calypso (mythology)|Calypso]], [[Clymene (mythology)|Clymene]], [[Asia (mythology)|Asia]], Electra) or personified abstract concepts ([[Tyche]], [[Peitho]]). One of these many daughters was also said to have been the consort of the god [[Poseidon]], typically named as [[Amphitrite]].<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 1.8</ref> More often, however, she is called a [[Nereid]].<ref>[[Hesiod]] ''[[Theogony]]'' 243; ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 1.11</ref> Oceanus and Tethys also had 3,000 sons, the river-gods [[Potamoi]] (Ποταμοί, "rivers").<ref>[[Hesiod]] ''[[Theogony]]'' 337</ref> Whereas most sources limit the term Oceanids or Oceanides to the daughters, others include both the sons and daughters under this term.<ref>Hyginus. ''Fabulae'', [http://www.theoi.com/Text/HyginusFabulae1.html Preface].</ref> [[Sibelius]] wrote an orchestral work called ''Aallottaret'' (''[[The Oceanides]]'') in 1914.{{Fact|date=April 2009}} ==See also== * [[List of Oceanids]] * [[Nereid]] * [[Siren]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.theoi.com/Nymphe/Okeanides.html Theoi Project - Oceanides] [[Category:Greek mythology]] [[Category:Roman mythology]] [[Category:Greek legendary creatures]] [[Category:Roman legendary creatures]] [[Category:Nymphs]] [[Category:Oceanids| ]] [[Category:Greek sea gods]] [[Category:Articles containing Ancient Greek-language text]]
